results.title: 'Rockthorpe' Tasmania.
results.brief_description: The story of the production of breeding ewes and rams required to maintain high quality Australian wool. Fifty years of experience at “Rockthorpe” stud farm in Tasmania, have produced the Polwarth sheep - a breed suited to both coastal and highland conditions. Shows how the use of a fleec measurement system, individual classification, and selection of breeding-stock brings outstanding results.
results.description: The story of the production of breeding ewes and rams required to maintain high quality Australian wool. results.title: 'On the wallaby track' by Frederick McCubbin, 1896
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Otton, David Muir, Art Gallery of New South Wales and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Australian eye I”.
A study of the painting by Frederick McCubbin, “On the Wallaby Track”. Other major works of McCubbin are examined and the influence upon him of French genre painter Bastien-Lepage is discussed.

results.title: 'Mount William from Mount Dryden'...by Eugene Guerard, 1857
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Otton, David Muir and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 17 of Series “The Australian eye III”.
Eugene Von Guerard, (affectionately known as ‘the father of the Gallery School’ Victoria, being founder), with his training in the naturalistic German school of Romanticism, was able to produce works that express reverence for nature’s mysterious processes as well as appreciation of the splendours of the untamed Australian landscape. The European concept of sublimity is discussed and some of Von Guerard’s most majestic works are studied.

results.title: 'Lake St Clair' by William Charles Piguenit, 1887
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Otton, David Muir and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The Australian eye III”.
A study of the painting “Lake St Clair” (1887), by William Charles Piguenit. Features a brief biographical description of the artist including his life works in terms of his travels and experiences with nature as Australia’s first important landscape painter born in Australia (Hobart, 1836-1914). His first important works began with his series on Lake St Clair. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: 'Justice' of the Red functionaries
results.brief_description: Inspired and colourful narration accompanies this montage of German propaganda designed to illustrate the worst tyrannies of a Soviet State. Shows the administration of justice in 1948 as applied under Ulbricht’s communist regime. Includes pictures taken in Soviet zonal courts, and interviews with judges who fled to the West. An example of cold-war era red-scare demagoguery.

results.title: 'Endeavour'
results.brief_description: H.M.N.Z.S. Endeavour takes the New Zealand party for the British Trans-Antarctic Expedition to the Antarctic. Members of the party carry out oceanographic research, help build Scott Base and restore Scott’s and Shackleton’s huts before the ship brings Sir Vivian Fuchs, Sir Edmund Hillary and other expedition members back to New Zealand

results.title: 'Down the hills to Berry's Bay' by Roland Wakelin
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Otton, David Muir and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Australian eye V”.
Roland Wakelin was a leading figure in the fight to gain recognition in Australia for modernism. “Down the hills” is a powerful composition, introducing a Post-impressionist approach to form and using the Impressionists technique of juxtaposing strokes of pure colour. Wakelin speaks of his ideas in the film.

results.title: 'Cos its naughty
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Children Thinking”.
Interaction between parent and child in the child’s growing understanding of right and wrong. How does the child know what a lie is? How he is to being understanding the framework of good and naughty imposed upon him by the adults?

results.title: Computer Games, Mi Sex
results.brief_description: Video clip for “Computer Games” (1979) by New Zealand band, Mi-Sex.

constellations_other.name: Beyond the game industry
constellations_other.description: While the game industry garners a lot of publicity, digital games have long been created outside the official industry, and the social and cultural significance of games has always exceeded official channels.
